questions.text: On average, how long does sperm maintain fertility within the female genital tract?

A 46-year-old male was involved in a car accident. CT brain of the patient was done, which revealed a counter - coup injury and a nerve exiting dorsally from the brainstem had been compressed against the tentorium. Which of the following nerves is being referred to in this case?

A 70-year-old woman presents with symptoms including visual loss, nausea, vomiting, weakness, menstrual changes, sexual dysfunction, increased urine, and unintended weight changes. MRI shows an enlarged pituitary gland located in the sella turcica, immediately posterior and superior to which structure ?
Which muscle would not be affected in a 15-year-old boy who suffered an arrow injury in the suboccipital triangle ?

A 9-year-old boy complains of numbness and tingling in both feet. The examination reveals no pulse in the femoral artery , increased blood pressure in the arteries of the upper extremities, and enlarged arteries . Which of the following abnormalities would you suspect ?
questions.correct_answer: C. Post-ductal coarctation of the Aorta

questions.text: A 24-year-old graduate student presents in the emergency department 10 days after sustaining a blunt force injury to the fifth finger of her non-dominant hand during a volleyball game. On examination, there's an inability to actively extend the distal joint, with slight tenderness and swelling on the dorsum. Suspected diagnosis: mallet finger. What causes a mallet finger?

options.label: B
options.text: Rupture of collateral slips of the extensor expansion

options.label: C
options.text: Rupture of the central slip of extensor expansion

questions.correct_answer: B. Rupture of collateral slips of the extensor expansion

questions.text: Which nerve structure is involved in innervation of the first part of the duodenum ?

A 2-day-old newborn baby presents to the physician with complaints of complete loss of breath and turning blue on several occasions. His breathing improves if the baby is placed in an upright or sitting position. Physical examination reveals an unusually flat stomach when the baby is lying down. On auscultation, there are no breath sounds on the left side of the thorax. What is the most probable diagnosis?
Which of the following is true regarding the origin of the fibers of the internal anal sphincter ?

options.label: A
options.text: Internal longitudinal muscle fibers of the rectum

options.label: B
options.text: Internal circular muscle fibers of the rectum

questions.correct_answer: B. Internal circular muscle fibers of the rectum

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 30 weeks of gestation presents to the obstetric clinic with rectal bleeding and severe pain while defecating for 4 days. According to her, the blood appears bright red when wiped with a tissue. She has complained of constipation on and off since the start of pregnancy. On physical examination, a bluish, tender perianal mass is seen. Which of the following nerve supply is responsible for the pain in this patient?

A 32-year-old male presents to the outpatient department due to weakness of knee extension for the last 2 months. On physical examination, paralysis of a muscle that originates from the femur was found. The muscle is also responsible for the stability of the knee joint. Which of the following muscles is most likely affected?
Which of the following signs, if present, will confirm an injury of the common peroneal nerve?
Which of the following best defines the basis for sensory inputs being converted into nerve impulses ?

If a patient has a creatinine clearance of 90 ml/min, a urine flow rate of 1 ml/min, a plasma K + concentration of 4 mEq/L, and a urine K + concentration of 60 mEq/L, what is the approximate rate of K + excretion?
A 34-year-old male amateur mountain climber has started climbing Mount Everest. Before his climb, he takes acetazolamide . What response is expected with this drug before the climb?

A group of pharmacists is trying to study the pharmacokinetics of a new drug. They want to calculate the extracellular volume of a test subject. 5g of mannitol has been injected intravenously. After equilibrium, 40% of mannitol is excreted and the plasma concentration of mannitol is 30 mg/d l. What is the volume of the fluid in which this substance is distributed?

Where

  • v: Volume of fluid
  • Q: Quantity of indicator given
  • C: Concentration of the indicator
  • e: The amount of indicator which has either been lost or metabolized

questions.text: Which neurotransmitter inhibits GnRH neurons before puberty?

A physiology demonstration is being held on fluid compartments. The professor explains that t o measure the volume of any fluid compartment within the body, you must inject or infuse a marker substance that will equilibrate (diffuse freely to a uniform concentration) throughout this compartment. To be a perfect marker, a substance must also not be metabolized. Furthermore, it must be possible to measure the concentration of the marker once the equilibration is complete. The most accurate extracellular fluid volume (ECF) measurement can be done by using?
questions.explanation:
Fluid Compartment Marker Substances
Total body water
  1. Deuterium oxide (D2O)
  2. Tritium oxide (T2O)
  3. Antipyrine
Extracellular fluid
  1. Radioactive sodium, chloride, bromide, sulfate and thiosulfate.
  2. Non-metabolizable saccharides like Inulin, mannitol, raffinose and sucrose.
Plasma
  1. Radioactive iodine (131I)
  2. Evans blue (T-1824)

questions.text: A 50-year-old elderly patient came to the emergency department with shortness of breath and generalized oedema, especially in his legs, for the last two days. On examination, he had basal crepitations and a rapid heart rate. The doctor suspects congestive cardiac failure. When capillary and interstitial hydrostatic pressures are 30 mm Hg and 10 mm Hg, respectively, colloid oncotic pressure in capillaries and interstitium are 22 mm Hg and 5 mm Hg, respectively. What will be the net filtration pressure of this patient?
Which of the following hormones is not involved in regulating food intake ?

One of your friends visits your clinic with his spouse and 3-year-old daughter. His blood type is A, Rh-positive, while his spouse has B, Rh-positive. The blood type of his daughter is O, Rh-negative. What is your comment about the relation between the three individuals, based on the given information?

options.label: A
options.text: The woman can be the child’s natural mother, but the man cannot be the natural father

options.label: B
options.text: The man can be the child’s natural father, but the woman cannot be the natural mother

options.label: C
options.text: Neither adult can be the natural parent of this child

options.label: D
options.text: This couple can be the natural parents of this child

questions.correct_answer: D. This couple can be the natural parents of this child

questions.text: A 27-year-old rugby player sustained a fracture to the right tibia after a collision injury. After his lower leg had been in a cast for 8 weeks, he found that the right gastrocnemius muscle was significantly smaller in circumference than it was before the fracture. This is due to:

options.label: A
options.text: Decrease in the number of individual muscle fibers in the muscle.

options.label: B
options.text: Decrease in blood flow to the muscle caused by constriction from the cast.

options.label: C
options.text: Temporary reduction in actin and myosin protein synthesis.

questions.correct_answer: C. Temporary reduction in actin and myosin protein synthesis.

questions.text: A pharmacist is trying to study the pharmacokinetics of a novel drug. He wants to calculate the plasma volume to study the drug distribution volume. He injected 1.5 mL of a solution containing 20 mg/mL of Evans blue dye into plasma; the final concentration of the dye was 0.015 mg/mL. Which of the following is the calculated volume of the plasma?
Which of the following is the basis for referred pain ?

options.label: A
options.text: Visceral pain signals and pain signals from the skin synapse with separate populations of neurons in the dorsal horn

options.label: B
options.text: Visceral pain transmission and pain transmission from the skin are received by a common set of neurons in the thalamus

options.label: C
options.text: Visceral pain signals are rarely of sufficient magnitude to exceed the threshold of activation of dorsal horn neurons

options.label: D
options.text: Some visceral pain signals and pain signals from the skin provide convergent input to a common set of neurons in the dorsal horn

questions.correct_answer: D. Some visceral pain signals and pain signals from the skin provide convergent input to a common set of neurons in the dorsal horn
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Learning Objective
  • ➤ Definition: Referred pain is the pain that is perceived at a site adjacent to or away from the site of origin. Deep pain and some visceral pain are referred to other areas. But, superficial pain is not referred. Examples of Referred Pain Cardiac pain is felt at inner part of left arm and left shoulder. Pain in ovary is referred to umbilicus. Pain from testis is felt in abdomen. Pain in diaphragm is referred to shoulder. Pain in gallbladder is referred to epigastric region. Renal pain is referred to loin.

  • ➤ Pain in ovary is referred to umbilicus.
  • ➤ Pain from testis is felt in abdomen.
  • ➤ Pain in diaphragm is referred to shoulder.
  • ➤ Pain in gallbladder is referred to epigastric region.
  • ➤ Renal pain is referred to loin.
  • ➤ Causes of Visceral Pain Ischemia: Substances released during ischemic reactions such as bradykinin and proteolytic enzymes stimulate the pain receptors of viscera. Chemical Stimuli: Chemical substances like acidic gastric juice, leak from ruptured ulcers into peritoneal cavity and produce pain. Spasm and Overdistention of Hollow Organs: Spastic contraction of smooth muscles in gastrointestinal tract and other hollow organs of viscera cause pain by stimulating the free nerve endings. Overdistention of hollow organs also causes pain.

  • ➤ Visceral pain fibers provide input to anterolateral tract cells that also receive somatic pain from the skin surface. The convergence of these two types of pain signals onto single spinal cord neurons is the basis for referred pain .

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with mild liver disease, arthritis, fatigue, and grayish skin pigmentation. A highly elevated level of iron is observed in his liver biopsy report. Which of the following conditions will be most likely found in this patient?

A newborn presents with severe respiratory distress and has not gained proper weight during the past several weeks. Examination revealed muscle hypotonia and neurological problems and an extremely low level of acetyl CoA carboxylase in liver. The most likely reason for an infant's respiratory problems is:

An enzyme catalyzing the reaction A + E → EA → E + P was mixed with 5 mM substrate concentration (compound A). The initial rate of formation of the product was 25% of V max . What is the K m value for the enzyme?
Which of the following constitutes the most suitable diagnostic test for confirming the presence of sickle cell anemia?

A 3-year-old child presents to the physician office with a history of arrested developmental growth since age 2, along with impaired cognition and poor vision. On physical examination, he has coarse facial features and a waddling gait. His mother states that he has a history of frequent respiratory infections. Laboratory examination of the child shows increased levels of glycosaminoglycans in urine. All of the following are f unctions of GAGs except

A 37-year-old woman presents in the emergency with the complaint of watery diarrhea and abdominal pain associated with flatulence after having a banana milkshake 4 hours ago. She has a medical history of undergoing chemotherapy for breast cancer diagnosed 3 months ago. Which enzyme deficiency is the most probable cause of the symptoms described?

A 5-year-old boy presents to the emergency department in an altered state of consciousness. After an extensive workup, blood biochemistry analysis shows a high lactate level and a reduced activity of α- ketoglutarate dehydrogenase. The most likely single enzymatic mutation that leads to these changes would be in which one of the following proteins?

options.label: A
options.text: The E3 subunit of pyruvate dehydrogenase

options.label: B
options.text: The E1 subunit of pyruvate dehydrogenase

options.label: C
options.text: The E2 subunit of pyruvate dehydrogenase

questions.correct_answer: A. The E3 subunit of pyruvate dehydrogenase

questions.text: A 42-year-man presents to the office for a follow-up visit. He was diagnosed with a urea cycle defect with very high blood glutamine and ammonium ion concentrations. The physician advises him to undergo phenylbutyrate treatment. Phenylbutyrate has which of the following effect on the patient?
A patient who is diagnosed with a deficiency of acetyl-CoA carboxylase will not be able to produce which of the following is an essential building block for fatty acid synthesis.
Among the following options, which serves as the indirect estimate of Lipoprotein-X?

A 55-year-old male presents to the outpatient department due to fatigue, paroxysmal dyspnea, and orthopnea . His past medical history is significant for hypertension for 15 years, for which he takes amlodipine. His family history is insignificant. An ECG reveals left axis deviation, and echocardiogram shows left ventricular hypertrophy. Hypertrophy can occur in cardiac, skeletal and smooth muscles. Which of the following does not represent the example of smooth muscle hypertrophy as an adaptive response to the relevant situation?

options.label: A
options.text: Urinary bladder in urine outflow obstruction

questions.text: An autopsy of the heart of an 85-year-old male who died of congestive heart failure 3 years ago has been performed, which shows the following findings as shown below: What is the predominant type of collagen found in the specimen of the heart ?
questions.explanation:
Types

Locations

Type I

Bone, skin, dentin, cornea, blood vessels, fibrocartilage, and tendon

Type II

Cartilaginous tissues

Type III

Skin, ligaments, blood vessels and internal organs

Type IV

Basement membrane in various tissues 

Type V

Blood vessel wall, synovium, corneal stoma, tendon, lung, bone, cartilage and skeletal muscle

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents with motor-dominant sensorimotor polyneuropathy, erectile dysfunction, and urinary incontinence. Transthyretin gene mutation was noted in genetic evaluation . The sural nerve biopsy specimen showed focal oedema and an amyloid deposit in the sub-perineural tissue, associated with moderate loss of myelinated and unmyelinated fibres. Which of the following disease is being described here?

A 14-year-old tall man has been presented to the clinic to get vaccinated for tetanus after falling in the park. Upon physical examination, the physician notices that he has long arms and legs with huge hands and feet. On further examination, sparse pubic and facial hair are noted along with gynecomastia. The size of his testes was also small. His mother reveals that he also has some learning disabilities. Which of the following chromosomal complement is most likely present in this male?

A 20-year-old female patient is brought by her mother with complaints of fever and cough for the last two days. She has been mentally disabled since birth. She is morbidly obese and has narrow shoulders. Upon further tests, maternal disomy of chromosome 15 is seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 9-year-old girl who is a known case of thalassemia visits to undergo a blood transfusion. Post transfusion, the patient has mildly elevated body temperature and generalized pruritis. Ideally, which of the following should be transfused in children suffering from thalassemia?

A 37-year-old male, who works as a coolie, complains of easy fatigability and recurrent Upper respiratory tract infections for the past 2 months. Physical examination reveals numerous petechiae over his body and mouth. The patient is a known case of Gouty Arthritis on medications. He also claims the usage of over-the-counter drugs for his body malaise. Abnormal laboratory findings include haemoglobin of 5.8 g/dL, WBC of 1,200/mL, and platelets of 18,000/mL. On further investigations, a diagnosis of Aplastic anaemia was made. Which of the following drugs are associated with the condition described above?
questions.explanation:
Drugs

A. Dose-dependent action – Cytotoxic drugs

B. Idiosyncratic action
  • Antibacterials (Sulphonamides, Chloramphenicol)
  • Anti-inflammatory drugs (Phenylbutazone, Indomethacin, piroxicam, Diclofenac, Naproxen)
  • Antirheumatics (Gold, penicillamine)
  • Antiepileptics (Phenytoin, Carbamazepine)
  • Antithyroids
  • Tranquilizers (Chlorpromazine)
  • Others-Furosemide, Allopurinol

Drugs

Chemicals

A. Dose-dependent action – Cytotoxic drugs
  • Benzene

B. Idiosyncratic action
  • Insecticides (Organophosphates, organochlorine)
  • Antibacterials (Sulphonamides, Chloramphenicol)
  • Pentachlorophenol (an antibacterial, fungicide & wood-preservative)
  • Anti-inflammatory drugs (Phenylbutazone, Indomethacin, piroxicam, Diclofenac, Naproxen)

  • Antiepileptics (Phenytoin, Carbamazepine)

  • Tranquilizers (Chlorpromazine)
  • Others-Furosemide, Allopurinol

Further lab investigations, EGD, and colonoscopy were carried out, which revealed diffuse hemorrhagic gastritis and severe colitis. CT scan abdomen and pelvis showed a cecal mass with localized lymphadenopathy. Histology and immunohistochemistry of biopsied specimens showed mantle cell lymphoma. questions.text: A 67-year-old male patient was brought to the emergency with complaints of blood and mucus mixed stools and tenesmus. The patient was pale and hemodynamically unstable. A colonoscopy was done, and a biopsy was taken. HPE showed a signet ring appearance. The barium meal study is shown in the image. Based on epidemiological studies, which of the following is most protective against the given disease?
questions.explanation:
ENVIRONMENTAL FACTORS & THEIR ASSOCIATED RISK TO CAUSE COLON CANCER:  
INCREASED RISK PROTECTIVE FACTORS
  • High intake of dietary lipids
  • Pelvic irradiation
  • Streptococcus bovis endocarditis
  • Ureterosigmoidostomy
  • High-fibre diet [Most protective]

  • Hormone Replacement Therapy [HRT]

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presents to the OPD with complaints of joint pain, rash on face, palm and shin, and weight loss. There is radiographic evidence of bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and interstitial lung disease . A lung biopsy gives findings similar to those shown in the figure. Which of the following is a major characteristic of this disorder?

options.label: B
options.text: Highest incidence in persons of Asian lineage

questions.text: A female, age 27, came to the hospital for a routine checkup . She has a history of smoking 20 cigarettes a day. Which of the following conditions is she maximally predisposed to?
questions.correct_answer: D. Squamous metaplasia of lactiferous ducts

questions.text: A 39-year-old male patient complained of an oral tumour . His chief complaint was painful swelling in the anterior gingiva , which made eating difficult. He noticed the swelling 6 months back in the upper anterior gingiva , which progressively increased in size and gradually involved the entire gingiva of both arches. The patient visited a local dentist, and oral prophylaxis was performed. No clinical changes were evident post-prophylaxis, and the lesion attained the present size within 7 days. For the previous 7-8 years, he chewed tobacco and lime 5-6 times a day, occasionally drinking alcohol . Microscopic and Immunohistochemical findings lead to the diagnosis of Lymphoma . Which of the following gene is associated with the pathology of the disease discussed here?

Macrophage activation occurs in 2 different pathways; Classical and Alternative pathways. According to different pathogens causing the disease, the pathways differ. Among the given options, which of the following leads to the activation of macrophages via the classical pathway?

A forty-three-year-old male presents to your clinic with the complaint of a lesion on his left hand. Examination of the dorsal surface of his left-hand shows a scaly erythematous lesion. A skin sample of the lesion shows abnormal keratinocytes covering the entire epidermis thickness. The arrows indicate apoptotic bodies in the image below. In this patient's skin cancer, which of the following proteins plays the most critical role in mediating programmed cell death?

A 53-year-old man complains of cough, weakness, and fever for four days. Pneumonia is diagnosed, and gentamicin is part of the treatment plan. Gentamicin has a half-life of 2-3 hours but can accumulate in the kidney with prolonged dosing, leading to a prolonged half-life of 53 hours. What type of half-life is this?

A 36-year-old woman with a history of recreational oxycodone use presents with irritability, nausea, and diarrhea , 48 hours after her last dose. Physical examination reveals mydriasis, rhinorrhea, and piloerection. Why does a drug similar to oxycodone, but without euphoria, provide different effects?

A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency with vomiting, dizziness, and abdominal cramps for 8 days. His relatives also told the doctor that he has been going for urination very infrequently and has had frequent loose, watery stools for 4 days. On examination, his BP is 80/50, and his lips and eyes are dry . The doctor prescribes a medicine to the patient. What was the medicine, and what is its dose in this case?
What centrally acting pro-drug converted to its active form in the brain might be prescribed for a patient discharged after experiencing fluctuating blood pressure following delivery ?

A 45-year-old presents to the ER with nausea, lethargy, weakness, anorexia, tremors, abnormal breathing, and confusion over six weeks . The basic workup shows significant hyponatremia . Further tests confirm the Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone (SIADH). What's the optimal next management step?
questions.correct_answer: C. Restriction of free water intake
questions.explanation:
Management Measures Examples/Drugs
Treat underlying cause - Discontinue causative medications
  - Treat underlying condition (e.g., lung diseases, brain disorders)
Fluid restriction - Limit fluid intake to 800-1000 mL/day
Sodium supplementation - Oral sodium chloride
  - Intravenous saline solutions
Pharmacological treatment - Demeclocycline
  - Vasopressin receptor antagonists (e.g., tolvaptan)
Correct electrolyte imbalances - Hypertonic saline (in severe hyponatremia)
  - Monitor and maintain electrolyte balance
Treat complications - Seizure management
  - Cerebral edema management
  - Cardiac arrhythmia treatment
Close monitoring - Fluid intake and output
  - Serum sodium levels
  - Urine osmolality
  - Clinical symptoms

questions.text: A 59-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of episodic cough and shortness of breath. The cough is nonproductive and worsens when she climbs stairs and at night. She has not had chest pain or palpitations. Eight weeks ago, she had an episode of fever, sore throat, and nasal congestion. She has a 10-year history of hypertension. She has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 16 years. Her only medication is enalapril. Her pulse is 78/min, respirations are 18/min, and her blood pressure is 145/95 mmHg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. Diffuse end-expiratory wheezes are heard on pulmonary auscultation. An x-ray of the chest shows no abnormalities. Spirometry shows a FEV1:FVC ratio of 65% and an FEV1 of 60%. The patient is given a salbutamol inhaler.. Which of the following is NOT a likely adverse effect of salbutamol in this woman?

A 44-year-old male presents to the clinic complaining of loose, watery stools and vomiting for the past two days. There were eight episodes for the past two days. The stool was watery and yellowish, and did not contain blood or mucus content. There was no history of abdominal pain, fever, or jaundice . On examination, the patient was lethargic . His blood pressure measured 100/60 mmHg, and his pulse rate was 80 beats per minute. Abdominal examination was unremarkable. The patient was given intravenous fluid and was prescribed diphenoxylate and atropine . Which of the following is the mechanism of atropine in this particular case?

options.label: B
options.text: Augment the anti-motility action of diphenoxylate

options.label: D
options.text: Discourage overdose and abuse of diphenoxylate

questions.correct_answer: D. Discourage overdose and abuse of diphenoxylate

questions.text: A 67-year-old female patient seeks evaluation at the clinic for her debilitating symptoms.. She has had hot flashes and urinary incontinence for the past few months. Her last menstrual cycle was 13 years ago. She is obese. After careful evaluation, a diagnosis of postmenopausal changes has been made . The attending doctor adds progestin to estrogen replacement therapy for 10-12 days each month. Which of the following is the primary reason for adding a progestin component to this patient's regimen?

options.label: A
options.text: Blocks the increased risk of myocardial infarction due to estrogen

options.label: B
options.text: Blocks the increased risk of endometrial carcinoma due to estrogen

options.label: C
options.text: Reverses vulval atrophy occurring in post menopausal women

options.label: D
options.text: Enhances the metabolic benefits of estrogen treatment

questions.correct_answer: B. Blocks the increased risk of endometrial carcinoma due to estrogen
questions.explanation:
Negative Effects  Positive Effects 
  • Breast tenderness 
  • Vaginal bleeding or spotting 
  • Enlarge fibroids 
  • Migraine headaches 
  • Abdominal bloating 
  • Nausea 
  • Skin rashes 
  • Increase triglycerides slightly 
  • Reduce hot flashes 
  • Less gain of abdominal fat 
  • Helps vulvar and vaginal atrophy 
  • Decreased incidence of osteoporotic fractures 
  • Reduce risk of colon cancer 
  • Improved pelvic musculature 
  • Reduces collagen loss in skin (fewer wrinkles) 

Increased risk of: 

  • MI/stroke risk in smokers 
  • Thromboembolic disease in smokers 
  • Breast cancer (MHT use)
  • Endometrial cancer (if no progestin)
  • Exacerbation of endometriosis 
  • Implicated in decreased cognition in women ≥ 65 years old 

No significant changes in or increased risk of: 

  • Total serum cholesterol 
  • Lipoprotein profiles 
  • Gallbladder disease 
  • Breast cancer (oral contraceptive use)

questions.text: A 48-year-old male undergoing Whipple’s procedure suddenly becomes rigid . His temperature rises to 104º F . The anaesthetist identifies it as a case of malignant hyperthermia. He starts the treatment with a skeletal muscle relaxant . Which of the following describes the correct mechanism of action for the skeletal muscle relaxant?

options.label: A
options.text: Reduces acetylcholine release from motor nerve endings

options.label: C
options.text: Inhibits the generation of muscle action potential

options.label: D

questions.text: The patient came to OPD with complaints of numbness in his feet. Physical examination of the feet reveals erythema, edema, and the presence of several clear blisters. Peripheral pulses are palpable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Frostnip

Superficial freeze injury that causes no tissue loss. Rewarming quickly reverses the symptoms.

First-degree

frostbite

 Partial skin freezing, erythema, edema, no blisters, and desquamation several days later.

Second-degree

frostbite

Full-thickness skin freezing, erythema, edema, clear blisters. Patients complain of throbbing and numbness.

Third-degree

frostbite

Extends into the subdermal plexus. The skin is blue or grey, and hemorrhagic blisters.

Fourth-degree

frostbite

Extend into the subcutaneous tissue, muscle, and bone. No edema and the skin is mottled and cyanotic.

He had a history of a viral infection that included a skin rash and conjunctivitis when he was just 8 months old, diagnosed with measles . What should be the recommended treatment for the condition mentioned above?
What is the treatment for heparin toxicity?
questions.explanation:
Aspect Description
Definition Heparin toxicity refers to adverse effects and complications resulting from the administration or use of the anticoagulant medication heparin.
Types of Heparin There are two main types: 1. Unfractionated Heparin (UFH) - Given intravenously or subcutaneously. 2. Low-Molecular-Weight Heparin (LMWH) - Subcutaneous administration, generally considered safer with fewer side effects.
Common Symptoms 1. Excessive bleeding (hemorrhage). 2. Thrombocytopenia (low platelet count). 3. Allergic reactions (rare). 4. Hemorrhage or hematoma at injection site (with subcutaneous administration).
Heparin-Induced Thrombocytopenia (HIT) A severe complication characterized by a paradoxical decrease in platelet count and an increased risk of blood clots.
Risk Factors - High-dose heparin therapy. - Prolonged use of heparin. - Certain medical conditions (e.g., cancer). - Previous exposure to heparin.
Management Treatment depends on the severity and type of toxicity but may include: 1. Immediate discontinuation of heparin. 2. Monitoring and correction of bleeding or clotting issues. 3. Switching to alternative anticoagulants. 4. Management of allergic reactions if present.
Prevention - Careful dosing and monitoring. - Regular assessment of platelet counts. - Awareness of patient-specific risk factors. - Consideration of alternative anticoagulants in high-risk cases.
Osteoporosis Risk Long-term use of heparin may contribute to osteoporosis and decreased bone density.
Neurological Effects In rare cases, heparin toxicity can affect the central nervous system, leading to neurological symptoms.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male was admitted with a 6-month history of rectal bleeding, anal discharge , and altered bowel habits . questions.text: A 40-year-old man, Vibhu presents with pulmonary lesions seen on a chest CT scan. He has a history of melanoma which was treated with wide local excision with negative margins and lymph node dissection. Biopsy of these pulmonary lesions proves to be metastatic melanoma. The general condition of the patient is good & there is no evidence of recurrence or extrathoracic disease. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Pulmonary metastasectomy followed by radiation therapy

questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Learning objective:
  • ➤ Melanoma is the most invasive skin cancer with the highest mortality rate. It accounts for only 1% of all skin cancers but has the highest cancer-related mortality. Even though it is serious skin cancer, it is highly curable if diagnosed early. It grows quickly and has the ability to metastasize to many organs including the lungs. In this patient, melanoma is already metastasized to the lungs but with no clinical symptoms. So the appropriate management for this patient is Pulmonary metastasectomy.

Size<=2cm stromal invasion <=1mm

1B

questions.explanation:
Changes of the Thyroid gland in pregnancy
  • Maternal changes include a marked and early increase in hepatic production of thyroxine binding globulin (TBG), and the peak levels are at 20 weeks.
  • hCG has intrinsic thyrotropic activity & high serum hCG levels from the placenta cause thyroid stimulation, thereby causing feedback inhibition of TSH. Hence, TSH levels in the first-trimester decline in more than 80 percent of pregnant women in the first trimester.
  • TRH levels remain normal
  • Thyroid gland itself is enlarged, But Free T3 and Free T4 are unchanged

10-15 Respiratory depression
12-15 Respiratory paralysis
25 – 30 Cardiac arrest

Clinical effects
4-7 Normal therapeutic level
8 – 10 Patellar reflex disappears
10-15 Respiratory depression
12-15 Respiratory paralysis
25 – 30 Cardiac arrest

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida presents with active labor at the 38th week of gestation. Emergency lower segment cesarean section is planned for the patient by the obstetrician. Which of the following is the true statement regarding the cesarean section?

options.label: A
options.text: Exteriorisation of the uterus for the repair of the uterine incision is a detrimental step and hence avoided

options.label: B
options.text: Two-layer closure of uterine incision is associated with significantly less risk of scar rupture

options.label: C
options.text: All incidental uterine fibroids should be excised during LSCS

options.label: D
options.text: Lower segment cesarean has a lower risk of scar dehiscence in next pregnancy compared to classical

questions.correct_answer: D. Lower segment cesarean has a lower risk of scar dehiscence in next pregnancy compared to classical
questions.explanation:
Aspect Information
Definition Surgical delivery of a baby through a horizontal incision on the lower segment of the uterus.
Indications 1. Fetal distress during labor.
  2. Abnormal presentation (e.g., breech or transverse).
  3. Placenta previa.
  4. Multiple gestations.
  5. Maternal medical conditions (e.g., hypertension).
Advantages 1. Lower risk of uterine rupture in future pregnancies.
  2. Faster recovery compared to classical cesarean.
  3. Reduced blood loss and postoperative pain.
  4. Lower risk of wound infection.
Surgical Technique Horizontal incision (transverse or low-vertical) on the lower segment of the uterus.
Anesthesia Regional anesthesia (epidural or spinal anesthesia) is most commonly used. General anesthesia may be used in specific situations.
Complications 1. Infection at the incision site.
  2. Postpartum hemorrhage.
  3. Adverse reactions to anesthesia.
  4. Injury to nearby organs (rare).
  5. Blood clots (deep vein thrombosis).
Recovery Most women can expect a hospital stay of 2-4 days after surgery. Full recovery may take 4-6 weeks. Activities like driving and heavy lifting are restricted during the recovery period.

questions.text: An 8-day-old neonate is brought to the emergency department due to severe vomiting for 1 day. Physical examination reveals hyperpigmentation of the skin, severe dehydration, and ambiguous genitalia. The laboratory investigations reveal serum glucose level of 44mg/dl, serum Na + 110mEq/L and K + 6.2mEq/L. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 4-year-old boy is brought to the hospital with difficulty walking. The mother reports that the child usually falls while walking and cannot climb stairs. Family history reveals a cousin , who died in his teenage, also had symptoms of muscle weakness . On physical examination, there is proximal muscle weakness in the lower limbs associated with pseudohypertrophy of the calf muscles . The patient started with Eteplirsen , which has been recently approved by FDA and shows s ome improvement. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?

A 5-year-old girl is brought to the paediatric outpatient department by her mother due to joint pains and morning stiffness for 3 months . It is associated with eye pain and photophobia. Her mother reports that the patient limps while walking, which is severe during the early morning hours. Physical examination reveals tender, swollen knees and ankles bilaterally . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.explanation:
7 types of
Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis

 

Systemic JIA
 

Affects the whole body.
Symptoms include high fevers, the child may feel very ill, appear pale, or develop a rash. The spleen and lymph nodes might become enlarged.

Oligoarthritis
 

Affects four or fewer joints, often the knee or ankle. Symptoms include pain, stiffness, or swelling in the joints.

Polyarticular negative
 

Symptoms include swelling or pain in five or more joints. The small joints of the hands are affected as well as the weight -bearing joints like the knees, hips, ankles, feet, and neck.

Polyarticular
positive

This type of JIA behaves the most like adult rheumatoid arthritis, and kids who have it have a rheumatoid factor (RF) or anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide n their blood.

Psoriatic
negative
 

Kids with this also have the psoriasis rash (a scaly red rash that can start behind the ears, on the eyelids, elbows, knees, or scalp) themselves or a close relative with psoriasis.

Enthesitis
related

This type of arthritis often affects the legs and spine. Kids also might have inflammation at the entheses areas where tendons join bones.

Undifferentiated

 

Arthritis that doesn't fit into any of the above categories or fits into more than one of the categories.

questions.text: A 5-month-old male infant is brought to the pediatric clinic by his parents with complaints of sudden, repetitive jerking movements of his arms and legs. The parents report that these episodes last a few seconds and occur multiple times throughout the day. Developmental milestones are delayed. On examination, you observe brief flexion and extension movements of the limbs during the episodes. The rest of the physical examination is positive for ash-leaf spots and periungual fibromas. Based on the clinical presentation, what is the drug of choice for the management of infantile spasms in this patient?

A 9-year-old boy is brought to an outdoor department with a history of decreased urine output, cola-coloured urine, and swelling of the face and hands for 2 days. On examination, he is hypertensive, has a puffy face, and pitting oedema of the lower limbs but is vitally stable. He has a history of skin lesions 4 weeks earlier. A diagnosis of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is made. ASO titers, in this case, will be?

options.label: D
options.text: Initially elevated, rapidly fall in 3-4 days

questions.explanation:
Aspect Description
Definition Poststreptococcal Glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is a type of acute glomerulonephritis, which is a form of kidney inflammation. It occurs following an infection with certain strains of group A Streptococcus bacteria, particularly after a streptococcal throat or skin infection, such as strep throat or impetigo.
Causative Organism Group A Streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes) is the causative organism responsible for PSGN. After the infection, the body's immune response produces antibodies, including antistreptolysin O (ASO), which can be measured through laboratory testing. Elevated ASO titers indicate a recent or recent past streptococcal infection.
Pathophysiology After the initial streptococcal infection, the immune system mounts an immune response, leading to the production of immune complexes. These complexes can deposit in the glomeruli (small filtering units) of the kidneys, triggering inflammation and damage to the kidney tissues, resulting in glomerulonephritis.
Clinical Presentation - Hematuria (blood in the urine)
  - Proteinuria (excess protein in the urine)
  - Edema (swelling), especially around the eyes, hands, and feet
  - Hypertension (high blood pressure)
  - Oliguria (decreased urine output)
  - Dark-colored, foamy urine
Diagnosis - Clinical history and physical examination
  - Laboratory tests: Elevated ASO titers, increased anti-DNase B titers, and decreased serum complement levels (C3 and C4) are typical findings.
  - Urinalysis: Presence of red blood cells and protein in the urine.
  - Renal biopsy (rarely required): To confirm the diagnosis and assess the severity of kidney damage.
Treatment - Supportive care: Rest, adequate fluid intake, and management of hypertension and edema.
  - Antibiotics: Antibiotics may be given to treat the underlying streptococcal infection and prevent further complications.
  - Diuretics: To help manage fluid retention and edema.
  - Antihypertensive medications: To control blood pressure if necessary.
  - Dietary adjustments: Limiting salt and protein intake may be beneficial in some cases.
Prognosis Most cases of PSGN have a good prognosis, especially in children. The majority of patients recover fully with supportive care and appropriate treatment of the underlying infection. In some cases, especially in adults with underlying health conditions, PSGN can lead to more severe kidney damage and may require further management.
Complications - Acute kidney injury
  - Chronic kidney disease
  - Hypertensive encephalopathy (rare)
  - Pulmonary edema (rare)
  - Heart failure (rare)

A 40-year-old woman neuro-fibromatosis II patient comes to the E.N.T. department with a 3-week history of intermittent episodes of dizziness. The episodes last for hours and are characterized by the sensation that the room is spinning. The patient also reports that she has started using her cell phone with her left ear because she hears better on that side. She has experienced intermittent ringing and fullness in her right ear. There is horizontal nystagmus to the right. M.R.I. revealed the below image. Which of the following audio-metric test is a reliable indicator in this patient?

A 47-year-old male was brought to the emergency department with an alleged history of RTA and sustained injury over the temporal area with leakage of blood from the nose. Which of the following bedside test is used to test the presence of CSF in the blood?

A 10-year-old male presented to the ENT outpatient department due to recurrent upper respiratory infections with denasal speech and was diagnosed as a case of chronic adenoid hypertrophy. The patient underwent adenoidectomy. He returns for the follow-up with the complaint of fluid leakage through the nose while eating. A 21-year-old female presents to the clinic with a complaint of hearing loss. Her general physical and systemic examinations were unremarkable. She has no associated symptoms , such as ear pain or discharge. There is no history of recent trauma or ear infection. She is not willing to take the upcoming college tests. A series of examinations revealed that the patient is malingering. Which one of the following tests would detect malingering?

A 70-year-old man presents to the hospital with difficulty swallowing for 3 weeks. He also complains of early satiety and regurgitation at night . On examination, he has bad breath . Following investigation was done for this patient. Which of the following does this X-ray demonstrate?

A 46-year-old male presented to the eye OPD with nasal congestion, postnasal drip, dark blood-tinged or purulent rhinorrhea, fever, and malaise associated with the left eye for the last two months . Physical examinations performed by an ophthalmologist reveal a necrotic area with black eschar formation on the palate, nasal septum, and skin of the eyelid. The patient also had a history of uncontrolled type 2 DM for the last ten years. Which fungus is most possibly associated with orbital cellulitis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Mu

  Mucormycosis
Definition Mucormycosis, also known as zygomycosis, is a rare but serious fungal infection caused by fungi belonging to the order Mucorales. It primarily affects immunocompromised individuals.
Causative Organisms - Common causative fungi include Rhizopus, Mucor, and Rhizomucor species.
  - Other genera within the Mucorales order may also be responsible.
Predisposing Factors - Immunocompromised conditions, such as uncontrolled diabetes mellitus, hematological malignancies, solid organ or stem cell transplantation, and corticosteroid use.
  - Trauma, burns, or surgical wounds that provide entry points for the fungus.
Clinical Presentation - Rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis (ROCM): Affects the paranasal sinuses, orbit, and can extend into the brain. Symptoms include facial pain, swelling, black eschar formation, and neurological deficits.
  - Pulmonary mucormycosis: Presents as pneumonia with symptoms like cough, chest pain, and fever.
  - Cutaneous mucormycosis: Involves the skin and may present with necrotic lesions.
  - Disseminated mucormycosis: Occurs in severely immunocompromised individuals and can affect multiple organs.
Diagnosis - Clinical evaluation with imaging (CT scans, MRI) to assess the extent of infection.
  - Histopathological examination of biopsy specimens for characteristic fungal hyphae with right-angle branching.
  - Fungal culture to isolate and identify the causative organism.
Treatment - Urgent surgical debridement to remove infected tissue.
  - Antifungal therapy with amphotericin B, posaconazole, or isavuconazole.
  - Control of underlying risk factors, such as diabetes control or reduction of immunosuppression.
Prevention - Maintaining good glycemic control in diabetic patients.
  - Reducing unnecessary corticosteroid use.
  - Strict aseptic precautions in healthcare settings.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presents to the emergency department due to sudden visual disturbances in the left eye. It is not associated with pain, nausea, vomiting, or headache. She has had a history of hypertension for 20 years and type II diabetes mellitus for 10 years. She is not compliant with her medications, and her HbA1c is 10%. Computerised static perimetry shows altitudinal field defects. A fundoscopic examination of the left eye shows: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

options.text: Lateral g eniculate b ody lesion

questions.correct_answer: A. Arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents to his family physician with complaints of vertical diplopia . He further explains that he feels unsure while descending stairs . He can eliminate the double vision by tilting his head toward the opposite side . The patient is otherwise vitally stable and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities. Which of the following extraocular muscles is responsible for ocular malalignment in this case?

A sixty-year-old male presents to your clinic with the complaint of blurry vision in his right eye for the past month. About a year ago, the patient underwent phacoemulsification surgery for cataract removal of the same eye. The defective vision was gradual in onset and was not associated with pain, redness or watering. According to the patient, his cataract surgery was uncomplicated, and his vision was perfect after surgery. The most common cause of this patient’s condition is?

A 40-year-old male presents to the ophthalmology OPD with a complaint of gradual painless vision loss for the last 3 months. He is unable to read a newspaper, particularly in bright sunlight. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Posterior subcapsular Cataract clinical features Image  Nuclear cataract

  • Hemeralopia [day blindness d/t constriction of pupil]
  • Decreased distant vision
  • Second sight [recovery of near vision; presbyopia resolves itself as it increases the refractive index]
Cortical/cuneiform cataract
  • Nyctalopia
  • Wedge-shaped cataract
Posterior subcapsular cataract / Cupuliform cataract
  • Cause maximum visual handicap & max glare [closest to the nodal point]
  • Cup-shaped cataract
  • Near vision is more affected than distant vision

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the physician within 6 weeks after sustaining a penetrating accidental injury to his left eye with a wooden stick. The patient has no other abnormalities. He gives no history of any chronic illness. He is vitally stable. On examination, there is a marked diminution of vision in the right eye associated with pain, redness and photophobia. Which of the following will be the first sign seen on the fundus examination of this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - Retrolental

questions.text: A 63-year-old male presents to the clinic for the evaluation of a lesion. He is a known case of hepatocellular carcinoma. On examination, the large, sharply defined circular patch is noted without any associated inflammatory changes. A diagnosis of pityriasis rotunda is made. Which of the following is true about this lesion?

A 5-year-old girl with a 3-month history of worsening vision and behavioral problems at school. Her mother received no prenatal care and reports that the girl was delivered without complications at home. Physical examination reveals that the girl is in the 30 th percentile for weight and the 35 th percentile for height. Additional findings that are notable for nummular keratitis, prominent notching of her upper two incisors and molars, and outward bowing of the tibia bilaterally. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Early Congenital Syphilis Late Congenital Syphilis
  • Extremely variable
  • Most infants asymptomatic at birth
  • 2/3 manifest- 3-8 weeks
  • By 3 months, most infants manifest
  • Contagious
  • Delayed consequences of localized inflammatory processes established at sites of treponemal infection during the early stage of disease
  • Seen beyond 2nd year of life
  • Correspond to - Tertiary stage of acquired syphilis
  • Non-infectious

  • BUENO’S TRIAD: Snuffles, Palmar & Plantar bullae, Splenomegaly
  • MARFAN’S DIAGNOSTIC PENTAD: Bueno’s triad, Pseudoparalysis, Cutaneous syphilis

Hutchinson's Triad– Pathognomonic sign

  • Interstitial keratitis
  • Eighth nerve deafness
  • Hutchinson’s teeth- Upper central incisors- Shorter, widely spaced, have a notch in biting edge- peg or screwdriver shape.

Cutaneous Lesions

  • Vesiculobullous rash- Pemphigus syphilitic – earliest,
  • Rash: Large pink macules, papules, plaques,
  • Condyloma lata,
  • Nail changes: Paronychia, claw nail, shedding of nails,
  • Hair changes: Alopecia, brittle sparse hair

Mucosal Lesions

  • Rhinitis(snuffles): Earliest watery nasal discharge thicker, purulent and bloody: Breathing and suckling difficulties
  • Pharyngitis & obstruction of the larynx occurs with characteristic hoarse cry (syphilitic aphonia) and cough

Skeletal Involvement

  • Osteochondritis of long bones: Earliest (upper end of tibia, the distal end of radius, and ulna)
  • Pseudoparalysis of Parrot- (Symptomatic- pain and tenderness)
  • Syphilitic Dactylitis: Painless, fusiform swelling of the digits; osteochondritis of phalanges.

Syphilitic Stigmata

  • Frontal bossing
  • Hot cross bun deformity- Parietal bone involvement
  • Olympian or beetled brow
  • A high cranium or "tower skull."
  • Saddle-nose deformity
  • Short maxilla, high palatal arch, prominent mandible- bulldog jaw
  • Scaphoid shape scapula
  • Circumoral radiating furrows (rhagades)
  • Hoarseness of voice
  • Higouménaki's sign – thickening medial third clavicle
  • Sabre tibia- Anterior bending of tibia
  • Mulberry Molar
  • Hutchinson's teeth
